Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Basis of Mechanosensitivity in Tactile Foraging Birds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Everything about the world surrounding organisms is perceived through senses. The sense of touch, or mechanosensitivity, is the ability to feel mechanical force through skin. Like the other senses, mechanosensitivity is vital for all aspects of everyday life in humans and other animals. It endows animals with the capacity to feel and explore the infinite richness of the tactile world. It is through mechanosensitivity that one perceives forces and textures that convey information about material properties, confer pain or evoke pleasure. Yet of all the senses that humans and other organisms possess, mechanosensitivity remains the least well understood from the cellular and molecular perspective. Only a very rudimentary understanding presently exists of how a breeze is felt and confidently identified, or how it is distinguished from a gentle touch, a blunt object or a mother's caress. This proposal seeks to shed light on the inner workings of mechanosensitivity, and then to disseminate this knowledge to schoolchildren. The results of this research will uncover fundamental principles of mechanosensitivity in vertebrates at the cellular and molecular level, and will be used further to incite interest in physiology in young audiences.

The proposal will approach its scientific goals from an unconventional perspective: through studying mechanosensation in species which have taken the sense of touch to the extreme - tactile foraging ducks. It is well known that the ducks can find food in murky water relying almost exclusively on the sense of touch in their bill and tongue. These organs are richly innervated by mechanosensory nerve fibers, which originate in the trigeminal ganglia and terminate in microorgans analogous to the mammalian Meissner and Pacinian corpuscles. The proposal focuses on uncovering the molecular prerequisites that enable the mechanosensitive neurons to convert mechanical force into electrical impulses, which then propagate to the brain signaling a physical contact. To accomplish this, differential transcriptomics will be employed to single out molecules that are enriched in the mechanosensitive nerve fibers of tactile foraging birds. Each of the candidate molecules will undergo electrophysiological tests for the ability to detect mechanical contact. The end-goal of this proposal is to uncover the molecular machinery through which neurons sense mechanical stimulation. These results, along with other aspects of sensory physiology, will be made available to young audiences through the Sensory Physiology Club - an extracurricular initiative conceived by the researchers of this project to promote scientific education among schoolchildren.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The sense of touch, or mechanosensitivity, is essential for all vertebrates, including humans, yet in comparison to other senses it remains poorly understood at cellular and molecular levels. How do we know we?ve encountered a physical object? How do we discriminate between a gentle touch, light brush, and painful punch? The molecular basis of these processes is unknown. Without understanding how mechanosensory ability is achieved at cellular and molecular level, full understanding of the principles of evolution of the mechanosensory and somatosensory systems in vertebrates is impossible. In this proposal, we approached this problem from the perspective of tactile specialist animals. The intellectual goal of this proposal was to obtain fundamental knowledge regarding basic principles of physiology and evolution of the sense of touch, and highlight general mechanisms of mechanosensitivity common to all vertebrates.

Some animals have taken the sense of touch to the extreme, providing an opportunity to look at the general problem of mechanosensation from the perspective of a tactile champion. One such example is tactile foraging ducks from the family Anatidae. Pekin duck (Anas platyrhynchos domesticus), a domesticated descendant of the Mallard, one the most sophisticated tactile foragers among vertebrates. In ducks the detection of tactile stimuli is mediated by mechanosensory corpuscles located in the glabrous (hairless) skin covering the duck bill and oral cavity. The corpuscles are innervated by mechanosensitive neurons (mechanoreceptors) from trigeminal ganglia (Figure 1). In this project, we performed functional, histological and bioinformatics investigation of the cellular and molecular mechanisms that allow ducks to achieve tactile specialization.

There are several major scientific outcomes of this proposal. We introduced Pekin duck as a laboratory model to study mechanosensitivity. This model will be further used by us and other laboratories to study the sense of touch. Our lab performed electrophysiological characterization of trigeminal neurons from Pekin ducks and showed that these cells constitute a majority of neuronal population in tactile foraging waterfowl. This work was featured on the cover of the PNAS journal and highlighted by several scientific media, including the Smithsonian magazine and Science Daily. We also developed a novel ex vivo electrophysiological approach to show that functionality of duck mechanosensory corpuscles completes in the egg. We demonstrated that the prevalence of mechanoreceptors in duck trigeminal ganglia is driven by a non-canonical developmental program that favors the appearance of numerous mechanoreceptors that mediate the detection of touch in the bill. This work appeared on the cover of the PNAS journal, was accompanied by a peer commentary and received media coverage in Science News. We revealed important details that govern the mechanics of the ion channel Piezo2, a key molecule that allows vertebrates, including humans, to sense mechanical touch. A key achievement of this project is the detailed electrophysiological and bioinformatics analysis of trigeminal neurons from eight species of visually and tactile foraging birds. We discovered that the expansion of mechanoreceptors in tactile foragers occurs at the expense of neurons that detect temperature and pain. This study revealed a general strategy for mechanosensory specialization in trigeminal ganglia of tactile specialist birds. We have published a book chapter on the Piezo2 channel, and a review on evolutionary aspects of tactile specialization in vertebrates. In summary, our studies revealed general principles of mechanosensory potentiation in somatosensory neurons of tactile specialist birds, with implication for other vertebrates.

Broader impact of this project was achieved through Sensory Physiology Club, an outreach program aimed to promote knowledge in various fields of physiology, with an emphasis on sensory biology. Using textbook-grade information as well as cutting edge scientific results from our laboratory, we teach the students how we feel touch, warmth and cold, how we see, smell or taste.  Our experimental activities include mechanosensitivity tests, studies of olfaction and taste, electrophysiological measurements in a cockroach leg, infrared light imaging, visual puzzles and more. The list is constantly changing and expanding, and is always tailored in accordance with the age of the school students. Each session takes 1.5-2 hours and is subdivided into short blocks to keep the young audience engaged.

Our audience are school students of different ages from public schools in Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York. We make a conscious effort to engage students from ethnic, racial and socioeconomic backgrounds traditionally underrepresented in science. Most of our trainees are female, underrepresented minorities, economically disadvantaged, or from families without prior college graduates. Sensory Physiology Club activities are designed and implemented by undergraduates, PhD students and postdocs from the laboratory, under close supervision of the principal investigator. This approach provides a unique teaching experience to our lab members, including undergraduate students, who thus receive an opportunity to communicate their science to a na?ve audience, and advance professionally to become educator-researchers. Under this award, we trained 680 school students, mostly from ethnic or economic groups underrepresented in science.
